title: Nuclear Deal Part Of £30bn China Trade Plan
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Oct 21, 2015, 08:24 BST - UK Markets close in 8 hrs 6 mins Nuclear Deal Part Of £30bn China Trade Plan By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News – 44 minutes ago View Photo 

Trade deals worth £30bn will be discussed later as David Cameron hosts Chinese President Xi Jinping at Downing Street. 
An announcement is expected on China's contribution to a new nuclear power plant which could open at Hinkley Point in Somerset by 2025. 
French energy firm EDF (Paris: FR0010242511 - news ) will build the plant, but Beijing is expected to cover around 30% of the £24bn cost. 
Among other initiatives being discussed is a £325m package of partnerships in the creative and technology industries, including a £50m deal between Aston Martin and China Equity to develop its zero-emission RapidE sports car. 
Britain will also make it easier and cheaper for Chinese tourists to visit the UK, in a bid to boost income from tourism and create more jobs. 
From January, the price of a two-year, multiple-visit UK visa will be slashed from £324 to £85 - the current cost of a six-month visa. 
And plans are also under consideration for the introduction of a 10-year, unlimited entry visa for regular Chinese visitors. 
Britain will also extend a mobile fingerprinting service from nine to 50 Chinese cities, allowing more people to easily undertake the biometric procedures required to apply for a visa. 
Announcing the moves, David Cameron said: "China is becoming one of our fastest-growing tourism markets so making it easier and more convenient for Chinese visitors to come to the UK is extremely important. 
"That is why the announcement I'm making today is great news for our tourism industry and great news for the British economy enabling us to maximise Chinese spending power even further." 
The trade announcements come as a poll for Sky News suggests the British public does not think that concerns about Chinese human rights should be downplayed. 
Sky Data suggests 48% of people think we should not develop closer economic ties with China until the Chinese government improves its human rights record. 
A similar number - 44% - think Mr Cameron should not decline to meet the Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama, even if a meeting damages Britain's economic ties with China. 
Mr Cameron has also promised the loss of hundreds of jobs in the steel industry will be on the agenda later. 
The talks come after the Queen hosted a state banquet in honour of Mr Xi at Buckingham Palace on the first full day of his visit to Britain. 
Speaking in Mandarin, Mr Xi told attendees: "As China-UK comprehensive strategic partnership enters the second decade this year, let us seize the opportunity and work together to usher in an even brighter future for China-UK relationship." 
:: The trade deals and job losses in the steel industry are likely to be hot topics during today's Prime Minister's Questions. Watch live on Sky News from 12 noon. 
:: Sky Data interviewed a nationally representative sample of 1,001 Sky (LSE: BSY.L - news ) customers online 16-19 October 2015. Data are weighted to the profile of the population.
